qas.question: What is always used the same way across fields?
What is poorly defined besides matter?
What does matter do in chemistry that it does not do in physics?
What is the combination of mass and matter called in chemistry?
What speed does matter travel at in physics?

context: Different fields of science use <b0_0>the term matter<b0_0/> in different, and sometimes incompatible, ways. Some of these ways are based on loose historical meanings, from a time when there was no reason to distinguish mass and matter. As such, there is no single universally agreed scientific meaning of the word "matter". Scientifically, the term "<b1_0>mass<b1_0/>" is well-defined, but "matter" is not. Sometimes in the field of physics "matter" is simply equated with particles that exhibit rest mass (i.e., that cannot travel at <b4_0>the speed of light<b4_0/>), such as quarks and leptons. However, in both physics and chemistry, matter exhibits <b2_0>both wave-like and particle-like properties<b2_0/>, the so-called <b3_0>wave–particle duality<b3_0/>.
